thread.title: Is fake news a threat to democracy? These MPs think so

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Is fake news a threat to democracy? These MPs think so
text:
News Is fake news a threat to democracy? These MPs think so Inquiry which saw MPs quiz executives from Facebook, Google and Twitter publishes dire warning about the impact of fake news Share Logo for Facebook (Image: PA) Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Russian anti-EU propaganda reached more people on Twitter than material from the official “Leave” campaign in the Brexit referendum.
It’s one example of the way social media is allowing “fake news” to spread, according to a hard-hitting inquiry.
And the result is that British democracy is under threat.
The warning comes from the House of Commons Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee, which includes Sunderland Central MP Julie Elliott.
MPs said: “Our democracy is at risk, and now is the time to act, to protect our shared values and the integrity of our democratic institutions.” A person using a laptop (Image: PA)
The ten-month inquiry saw MPs quizzing executives from Facebook, Google and Twitter, as well as Government ministers, academics and managers from traditional news media.
But Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s founder and chief executive, refused to speak to the MPs. Read More Fake News! Six times Twitter fooled the world
One person who did give evidence was Arron Banks, the head of pro-Brexit campaigners Leave.EU - but he walked out after answering questions for three hours saying he had to go to lunch.
The inquiry warned that social media firms not only allowed people to spread information which was blatantly untrue, but also encouraged the spread of “hyper-partisan” stories and posts, “which play to the fears and the prejudices of people, in order to alter their voting plans”.
MPs highlighted the influence of broadcaster Russia Today (RT) and news agency Sputnik, both owned by the Russian Government. Leave.EU founder Arron Banks and Andy Wigmore (left) (Image: PA)
One study found “that RT and Sputnik had more reach on Twitter for anti-EU content than either Vote Leave or Leave.EU, during the Referendum campaign.
“A joint research project by the Universities of Swansea and of Berkeley, at the University of California, also identified 156,252 Russian accounts tweeting about #Brexit and that they posted over 45,000 Brexit messages in the last 48 hours of the campaign.”
The committee said they “heard evidence of a co-ordinated, long-standing campaign by the Russian Government to influence UK elections and referenda, and similar evidence of foreign interference is being investigated by the US Congress in respect of the 2016 US Presidential Election.”
But Facebook refused to provide information about the scale of the problem, the MPs said: “Throughout this inquiry, from October 2017 to June 2018, we attempted to gain information from Facebook about the extent of Russian interference in UK political campaigns. “Time and again, Facebook chose to avoid answering our written and oral questions, to the point of obfuscation.”
The Committee said: “Urgent action needs to be taken by the Government and other regulatory agencies to build resilience against misinformation and disinformation into our democratic system.” Like us on Facebook
